Spectra of graphs
In this chapter we give methods for investigating the eigenvalues of a graph.
Let \Gamma be a graph of order v. The adjacency matrix of \Gamma, A(\Gamma), is the v\times v matrix indexed by V(\Gamma) such that A(\Gamma)_{xy}=1 if xy\in E(\Gamma), and A(\Gamma)_{xy}=0 otherwise.
The spectrum of \Gamma, Spec(\Gamma), is the multiset of eigenvalues of its adjacency matrix, and an eigenvalue of \Gamma is a member of Spec(\Gamma). The multiplicity of an eigenvalue \alpha of \Gamma is the number of times \alpha appears in Spec(\Gamma).

Eigenvalues of regular graphs
In this section, we introduce methods for investigating eigenvalues of regular graphs. The input for these methods will be a specific graph or the parameters of a graph.
Let \Gamma be a regular graph with parameters (v,k). Then \Gamma has largest eigenvalue k (see ). Therefore we do not implement a LargestEigenvalue function for regular graphs.
Let \Gamma be a strongly regular graph with parameters (v,k,a,b). The eigenvalues of \Gamma and their corresponding multiplicites are uniquely determined by the parameters (v,k,a,b) (see ). Using this knowledge, we provide methods which take as input feasible strongly regular graph parameters (v,k,a,b). We also give methods which return an exact representation of the eigenvalues of a strongly regular graph with parameters (v,k,a,b), and their multiplicities.
